item.title: Renderable Nodes
item.description:
Basic Nodes That Show Things
• Rectangle
• Label
• Poster

item.title: Z-Order/Parent-Child
item.description:
Scene Graph Tree Order Matters
Demonstrates the basic concepts of Scene Graph element layering and inheritance. In Roku Scene Graph, what's on the bottom of your XML tree goes on top!

item.title: Animations
item.description:
Fly Things Around and Flash Lights
This shows you how to make your application more moving, by animating screen elements. There are examples for all of the field interpolator nodes, plus sequential and parallel animations.

item.title: Events and Observers
item.description:
React When Stuff Happens
You need to handle events that come from both the user, and program actions. You'll learn to use the onKeyEvent() and observeField() Scene Graph functions to do this.

item.title: Typography
item.description:
Get It In Writing
You'll want to use text here and there in your application, so Scene Graph gives you several special nodes and features when a paragraph is worth a thousand posters.

item.title: Control Nodes
item.description:
Get Control Over Your Application
These nodes let you get complete control over your application program flow, download server data, and change your program behavior.

item.title: Lists and Grids
item.description:
List Things and Show Things
Every group of items you want to present to a user can be shown using a list or grid node class. Roku Scene Graph allows you easily format these groups from your current content catalog, with as much content meta-data and graphic images as you need for each item, then lets you program custom user focus and selection actions.

item.title: Dialogs
item.description:
Communication Should Go Both Ways
Scene Graph provides a full set of dialog nodes to allow you to convey information about the status of your application to users, and let them select options for moving forward.

item.title: Widgets
item.description:
Gadgets For Your Application
Buttons, text entry boxes, pin pads, even full keyboards, Roku Scene Graph has them all. Drop these into your application as needed, mix and match.

item.title: Layout/Groups
item.description:
Get Your Widgets in Order
Assume control over the layout of your component sub-elements.

item.title: Sliding Panels
item.description:
Let the User Interface Move Itself
Roku Scene Graph has pioneered a new intuitive user interface scheme that lets you break down your application screens into panels that slide into view based on the context of user choices. The latest Roku homescreen uses these sliding panels, and your application can use them too.

item.title: Media Playback
item.description:
Let The Show Begin
The final destination for video (and audio) on-demand applications.
